Graphical abstract Ceria-based solid solutions were synthesized and used as supports to prepare MnO x /Ce0.8Ti0.2O2 and MnO x /Ce0.8Sn0.2O2 catalysts (Mn/CeTi and Mn/CeSn) for low temperature selective catalytic reduction of NO by NH3. The effects of Ti or Sn doping on the catalytic performance of MnO x /CeO2 catalyst were investigated. Experimental results show that doping of Ti or Sn increases the NO removal efficiency of MnO x /CeO2. The NO conversion of Mn/CeTi catalyst is more than 90% at temperature window of 175–300°C under a gas hour space velocity of 60,000mLg−1 h−1. Modified catalysts are also found to exhibit greatly improved resistance to sulfur-poisoning. Characterization results indicate that doping of Ti or Sn brings about catalysts with higher BET surface area, enhanced oxygen storage capacity and increased surface acidity. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of spent catalysts following SCR reaction in the presence of SO2 verify that the loss of surface Mn species was inhibited by doping of Ti, which contributes to extend the sulfur durability. The SCR activity is considered as well to be promoted by the dual redox cycles in Mn/CeTi (Mn4+ +Ce3+ ↔Mn3+ +Ce4+, Ce4+ +Ti3+ ↔Ce3+ +Ti4+) and Mn/CeSn (Mn4+ +Ce3+ ↔Mn3+ +Ce4+, 2Ce4+ +Sn2+ ↔2Ce3+ +Sn4+) catalysts. Keywords Ceria-based solid solution Ti (Sn) doping Mn based catalyst Low temperature NH3–SCR reaction 1 Introduction The abatement of nitrogen oxides (NO x ) emission from exhaust gases of diesel and stationary sources is a significant challenge for economic and social development. Among implementable technologies, the selective catalytic reduction of NO x using ammonia as a reducing agent (NH3–SCR) has proved to be a cost-effective, reliable, and fuel-efficient way to control NO x emission, especially for stationary sources such as power boilers and combustion furnaces [1]. Commercial catalysts for this process is V2O5/TiO2 promoted by WO3 or MoO3, which works at 300–400°C to prevent pore plugging from the deposition of ammonium sulfate [2]. When the temperature of exhaust gas is below 280°C, NO x reduction efficiency decreases significantly. Reheating the exhaust gas has been used in certain applications but is costly. These circumscriptions make it necessary to develop new catalyst that can adapt to actual conditions. Low-temperature SCR catalysts located downstream of the desulfurizer and electrostatic precipitator can avoid the decrease of performance and longevity caused by high concentration of dust and SO2. Therefore, the development of novel catalysts for low temperature SCR with high performance becomes particularly important. In the last years, Mn based catalysts have attracted considerable attention in this reaction for their various types of labile oxygen which results in relatively high conversion of NO x at low temperature. Examples of these catalysts are supported MnO x catalysts such as MnO x /TiO2 [3], MnO x /Al2O3 [4], MnO x /AC [5], MnO x /NaY [6], MnO x /ZSM-5 [7] and unsupported catalysts like amorphous MnO x [8], CuO–MnO x [9], and MnO x –CeO2 [10] mixed oxides. However, there are a few amounts of SO2 even after desulfurizer which makes the low-temperature Mn catalysts deactivated. Improvement of the sulfur resistance for Mn based catalysts is a pressing issue at present. Unsupported oxide catalysts are not suitable for industrial application due to its high pressure loss. Supported catalyst, by contrast, is a better candidate for its good thermal stability, strong mechanical strength, high specific surface areas and dispersion of active components. Furthermore, studies have demonstrated that the choice of the support is crucial to obtain a superior catalyst in the NH3–SCR reaction [11]. Among various supports, ceria has unique advantages owing to its oxygen storage capacity (OSC) associated with the formation of oxygen vacancies and facile Ce4+/Ce3+ redox cycle. CeO2 was used as a catalyst in NH3–SCR and promoter in the three way catalyst (TWC) [12]. Moreover, it has been proved that ceria can enhance the NO x adsorption, provide stronger Brønsted acid sites, enhance the oxidization of NO to NO2 and improve sulfur resistance, which was beneficial for the NH3–SCR reaction [13]. However, pure CeO2 is not suitable for the practical application because of the small specific surface area and the low thermal stability [14]. One of the efficient methods to restrain this effect and improve the property of CeO2 support is incorporating foreign metal cations into the lattice of CeO2 [15–17]. It has been reported that doping of Ti or Sn in CeO2 can modify the catalyst surface area and insertion of doping ions improve the lattice oxygen mobility, resulting in a better redox quality [18]. Solid solutions of Ce1−x Ti x O2 and Ce1−x Sn x O2 have been reported by Baidya et al. [19] to show high OSC. It has also been reported that TiO2 can enhance the oxygen mobility by the creation of oxygen vacancies due to a better reducibility of the TiO2 (Ti4+ into Ti3+), supplying the Lewis acid sites for the adsorption and dissociation of molecules [20]. However, there are not enough attention be concentrated upon the effect of doped metal cation on MnO x /CeO2 for the NH3–SCR reaction. Furthermore, as an approach to improve the sulfur-poisoning resistance of Mn based catalyst for NH3–SCR, the role of Ti, Sn doping is expected to be made clear. Therefore, the related work is supposed to be further perfected. In the present work, Ti or Sn is introduced into CeO2 as a dopant to support manganese oxides and effect of the doping on catalytic performances of MnO x /CeO2 catalysts in low temperature NH3–SCR was investigated. The purpose is mainly focused on: (1) investigate the effect of Ti or Sn doping on the structure, texture, properties and SCR catalytic performance of the MnO x /CeO2 catalyst; (2) try to improve the catalytic performance and sulfur resistance of Mn based catalysts through the modification of the support. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Ce0.8M0.2O2 (M=Ti4+, Sn4+) solid solutions (Ce:M=4:1 molar ratio) were prepared by inverse co-precipitation method. Requisite quantity of ammonium cerium(IV) nitrate as host precursor was dissolved in distilled water to form a solution. Guest precursor of Ti or Sn (titanium(IV) tetrachloride or tin(IV) tetrachloride) was also added into distilled water, respectively. The above two solutions were mixed together and stirred for 2h, and then slowly added into the excess ammonia (25%) with vigorous stirring until pH 10. The resulting solutions were kept in stirring for another 3h, followed by aging for 24h. The precipitate was filtered, washed several times with distilled water until no pH change and no Cl− (detected by the solution of AgNO3). Finally, the obtained cakes were oven dried at 110°C for 12h and calcined at 550°C in the flowing air for 5h. In addition, pure CeO2 was prepared via the same procedure for comparison. These synthesized samples were CeO2, Ce0.8Ti0.2O2, and Ce0.8Sn0.2O2 supports (hereafter denoted as CeO2, CeTi, and CeSn). The catalysts were prepared by wetness impregnation method with Mn(CH3COO)2 solution. The solution of precursor and support was kept in stirring for 2h and evaporated at 100°C during the oil bath. The resulting materials were dried at 110°C for 12h in the oven and calcined at 500°C in the flowing air for 5h. MnO x loading amount was 0.5mmol/g-support and the catalysts are labeled as Mn/CeO2, Mn/CeTi and Mn/CeSn, respectively. The used catalysts in the SO2 containing SCR reaction are labeled as Mn/CeO2–S, Mn/CeTi–S and Mn/CeSn–S. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The BET surface area was obtained by N2-physisorption at 77K on a Micromeritics ASAP-2020 analyzer. Prior to each analysis, the catalyst was degassed under vacuum at 300°C for 3h. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were characterized by powder X-ray diffractometer (Bruker D8 Advance) with Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.5406Å). The intensity data were collected over a 2θ range of 10–80°. The scan speed was set at 10°min−1 with a step size of 0.02°. The mean crystallite sizes (D β ) were determined by Debye–Scherrer equation (D β = Kλ/β cos θ). Laser Raman spectra (LRS) were collected on a Renishaw invia Laser Raman spectrometer using an Ar+ laser beam with an excitation wavelength of 514nm. H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were performed in a quartz U-type reactor with Ar–H2 mixture (7.0% of H2 by volume, 70mLmin−1) as a reductant. The consumption of hydrogen was measured with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). After N2 pretreatment at 200°C for 1h, the TPR started from 50°C to target temperature at heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed on a PHI 5000 VersaProbe system, using monochromatic Al Kα radiation (1486.6eV) operating at an accelerating power of 15kW. The sample charging effects were compensated by calibrating all binding energies (BE) with the adventitious C 1s peak at 284.6eV. NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) experiments were carried out on a multifunction chemisorption analyzer with a quartz U-tube reactor, detected by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). About 100mg sample was pretreated by passage of highly purified He (40mLmin−1) at 450°C for 1h. After that, the sample was saturated with highly purified NH3 (40mLmin−1) at 100°C for 1h and subsequently flushed with He for 1h to remove gaseous and weakly adsorbed NH3, then heated from ambient temperature to 700°C at a rate of 10°Cmin−1 in the flowing highly purified He. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (in situ DRIFTS) were collected from 650 to 4000cm−1 at a spectral resolution of 4cm−1 (number of scans, 32) on a Nicolet 5700 FT-IR spectrometer equipped with a high-sensitive MCT detector cooled by liquid N2. The sample was pretreated with a high purified N2 stream at 300°C for 1h to eliminate the physicsorbed water and other impurities. At ambient temperature, the sample was exposed to a controlled stream of NH3–N2 (1% of NH3 by volume) or NO–N2 +O2–N2 (1% of NO and 5% of O2 by volume) at a rate of 50mLmin−1 for 1h to be saturated. And then, the gaseous and weakly adsorbed molecules were purged by a highly purified N2 stream (50mLmin−1). Desorption/reaction studies were performed by heating the adsorbed species and the spectra were recorded at various target temperatures at a rate of 10°Cmin−1 by subtraction of the corresponding background reference. 2.3 Catalytic performances tests The catalytic performances for the selective catalytic reduction of NO by NH3 in the presence of excess oxygen were determined under steady state, involving a feed stream with a fixed composition, 500ppm NO, 500ppm NH3, 5% O2, 100ppm SO2 (when used), and N2 in balance. The sample (100mg) was fitted in a quartz tube and pretreated in a high purified N2 stream at 300°C for 1h and then cooled to room temperature. After that, the mixed gases were switched on. The reactions were carried out at different temperatures with a space velocity of 60,000mLg−1 h−1. The concentrations of NO, NH3, NO2, and N2O were measured at 150°C by a Thermo fisher IS10 FTIR spectrometer equipped with a 2m path-length gas cell (250mL volume). The NO conversion and N2 selectivity were calculated from the following equations: NO conversion ( % ) = [ NO ] in − [ NO ] out [ NO ] in × 100 % N 2 selectivity ( % ) = [ NO ] in − [ NO ] out + [ NH 3 ] in − [ NH 3 ] out − [ NO 2 ] out − 2 [ N 2 O ] out [ NO ] in − [ NO ] out + [ NH 3 ] in − [ NH 3 ] out × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characteristics (XRD and LRS results) As revealed in XRD patterns (Fig. 1 a,b), all the samples exhibit the fluorite type crystalline structure without any phase segregation, characteristics of CeO2 (PDF-ICDD 34-0394). The average grain size is calculated by the Scherrer equation based on the XRD data and presented in Table 1 . Diffraction peak belongs to TiO2 or SnO2 is not detected in the XRD profiles of CeTi and CeSn. Moreover, the diffraction peaks of CeTi and CeSn shift slightly to higher angle as compared to the pure CeO2 (insert figure in Fig. 1a), indicating the formation of solid solution. Grain size of CeTi and CeSn is smaller than that of CeO2 when the introduction of Ti4+ and Sn4+ inhibiting the crystal growth of the cubic phase [21]. The decrease of lattice parameters for CeTi and CeSn samples also provided evidence that Ti4+ or Sn4+ ions are incorporated into ceria lattice by considering the radius of Ti4+ ions (0.68Å) and Sn4+ ions (0.71Å) are smaller than Ce4+ ions (0.92Å) [22]. After the impregnation of MnO x , all of the samples maintain their original crystal structure and no crystalline phase ascribed to manganese oxide can be found. It suggests that manganese oxide is finely dispersed on the supports as a non-crystalline phase or the particle size is smaller than the limitation of XRD. The incorporation of Ti or Sn to the fluorite lattice of CeO2 is also proved by Raman spectra displayed in Fig. 1c,d. All of the Raman spectra reveal a main band around 460cm−1 which was ascribed to the triply degenerate F2g mode of fluorite ceria. It should be noted that CeTi and CeSn showed a red shift in the main F2g mode band and the intensity decreased by comparing of Raman spectra of the CeO2. This shift implies that changes in the lattice parameter have occurred. Another reason of peak shifting and broadening may be the presence of oxygen vacancies, corresponding to stoichiometry CeO2−σ , which is related to a change of CeO2 environment in the presence of Ti or Sn due to the formation of solid solution [23]. This distinction offers a further indication of Ti and Sn has incorporated into the CeO2 framework. Raman spectroscopy can be useful to detect oxygen sublattice distortions and the existence of oxygen vacancies in ceria-based materials. A broad band at about 600cm−1 can be observed, which is commonly related to the presence of oxygen vacancies, and the doped samples show a relatively larger intensity compared to that of pure CeO2. Since the bands ∼275 and ∼600cm−1 are related to oxygen vacancies [24], the area ratio of (A 275 + A 600)/A 460 can reflect the concentration of oxygen vacancies (insert figure of Fig. 1d). We presume that the substitution of Ce4+ by Ti4+ or Sn4+ in the crystal lattice introduces additional lattice perturbation and structural stress with producing more surface defects. The oxygen vacancies (Vo) might result in the transformation of Vo+O2 +e– →adsorbed oxygen (O2 −, O2 2−, O−), and the enhancement of oxygen storage and release capacity between Ce3+ and Ce4+. Surface defects are active sites for the absorption of O2 and NO oxidation which possibly contributes to the NH3–SCR activity [25]. To complement the structural analysis, high-resolution micrographs of the supports have been recorded (Fig. S1). The images generally show the presence of aggregates of multiple nanoparticles displaying lattice fringes whose interplanar distances are compatible with the presence of the fluorite ceria phase. Ti or Sn containing phase can not be resolved in the multiple pictures, which also evidence that Ti and Sn are effectively incorporated into CeO2. 3.2 Catalytic performance results Fig. 2 shows the results of activity measurements over Mn/CeO2, Mn/CeTi, and Mn/CeSn catalysts as a function of reaction temperature. The NO conversion for all of the catalysts increase with the rising of temperature up to 250°C and then decrease slowly. The maximum activity values are 99.8%, 90.8%, and 78.9% for Mn/CeTi, Mn/CeSn, and Mn/CeO2, respectively. The NO conversion of Mn/CeTi can be maintained above 95% from 175 to 300°C at a space velocity of 60,000mLg−1 h−1, while Mn/CeO2 only provide nearly 60–78%. Compared to Mn/CeO2, an enhancement of about 25% is observed for Mn/CeTi in the range of 175–375°C and 10% for Mn/CeSn. It indicates that the low temperature SCR activity was improved with the addition of Sn or Ti, and the positive effect of Ti is more outstanding than Sn. N2 selectivities of these three catalysts decreased as the temperature rises. This may be ascribed to that more NH3 were oxidized by O2 with the rising of temperature. Fortunately, N2 selectivity are improved after doping of Ti or Sn significantly. Mn/CeTi possesses the best N2 selectivity among these catalysts to remain 70% until 300°C. This suggests the positive role of Ti and Sn in the reaction and the doped Mn/CeO2 catalysts are potential formulation for SCR reaction below 300°C. The resistance to SO2 poisoning of the catalysts during SCR of NO with NH3 was demonstrated in Fig. 3 through a long-time continuous test. After SO2 switching on, the NO conversion over all the catalysts exhibited a decrease. Nonetheless, Mn/CeTi and Mn/CeSn can maintain the NO conversion of about 90% and 65% after 10h SO2 resistance while Mn/CeO2 was deactivated rapidly and decreased to 30%. The 10h life test without SO2 showed no activity decline for all the catalysts which convinced us that the deactivations in Fig. 3a were caused only by SO2 (the results are not shown here). So, the Mn/CeTi and Mn/CeSn have much better resistance to the poisoning of SO2 than the Mn/CeO2 catalyst. What's more, the N2 selectivities of all the catalysts are elevated sharply with the addition of SO2 under the test condition. The N2 selectivitiy in the presence of SO2 maintains at 97% for Mn/CeTi and Mn/CeSn and 85% for Mn/CeO2 after 10h reaction. It is probably because that oxidation of NH3 by O2 was inhibited on the surface of sulfated catalyst in the SO2 containg gas. The NH3 +O2 reaction was conducted on the fresh catalysts and catalysts spent in SO2 containg reaction. As shown in Fig. S2, the NH3 conversion in NH3 +O2 reaction decrease from ca. 90% to 10% after be used in the SO2 containing reaction. Clearly, existence of SO2 greatly suppresses the NH3 oxidation activity and lead to high N2 selectivity of SCR (Fig. S3). Combining this fact with the increase of N2 selectivity with SO2 addition, NH3 is suggested to partly escape from being oxidized by O2 in SO2 containing gas, allowing the proceeding of NO reduction. Above results implicates that the sulfur resistance of the Mn/CeO2 catalyst is improved by doping of Ti or Sn. In order to further explore the reason for the difference of the catalytic performance and sulfur resistance, these samples are characterized by a series of techniques and the corresponding results are discussed in the following sections. 3.3 Textural characterization (N2-physisorption) The N2 adsorption–desorption isothermal plots and the corresponding BJH pore size distribution curves of the supports and catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . The isotherms of these samples are classical type IV as defined by IUPAC [26], which is characteristic of mesoporous materials due to the textural of inter-particle mesoporosity. This H2-type of the hysteresis loop is observed, which is typical for wormhole-like mesostructure and interstice mesoporous structure formed by nanoparticle assembly. Furthermore, the pore size distribution curves determined by the BJH method indicate that these samples possess uniform mesopore size distributions. The textural data are listed in Table S1. After Sn or Ti are doped into the lattice of CeO2, the specific surface area increase from 47.9 to 124.9, 134.5m2 g−1, respectively, accompanied with the increase of the pore volume. This favors better dispersion and anchoring of the active component and could enhance durability of the catalyst. Texture property of Mn/CeO2 catalyst is suggested to be effectively improved by doping of Ti or Sn for the enlarged surface area and decreased grain size. Through the characterization of catalysts used in the SO2 containing reaction, surface areas of the catalysts are found to decrease to 27.6 (Mn/CeO2), 57.2 (Mn/CeTi), 67.5 (Mn/CeSn)m2 g−1. This complies with the preceding demonstration that ammonium sulfate was formed and deposited on the catalyst during the reaction. All the catalysts show a half decrease in the surface area owing to the deposition of ammonia sulfate. But NO conversion of Mn/CeTi shows almost no decline after 10h, while Mn/CeSn and Mn/CeO2 suffered a drop to 65% and 30%, respectively (see Fig. 3). Additionally, the reduction peak areas of ammonia sulfate in the H2-TPR of the spent catalysts were subject to an order of Mn/CeTi–S>Mn/CeSn–S>Mn/CeO2–S (show in Fig. S4). Although having obviously more ammonium sulfate deposited, the catalyst Mn/CeTi was not much deactivated in 10h, whereas the Mn/CeO2 was quickly deactivated at rather low ammonium sulfate deposition. In view of the two commonly proposed reasons of deactivation by SO2: (1) Formation of ammonia sulfate and their deposition on the surface of catalysts which could cause pore plugging. (2) Sulfation of the metal oxide and their inactivation for the NH3–SCR ability. Deactiviation of Mn active species rather than pore plugging of the catalyst is considered to be the primary cause for the poisoning by SO2 in our test. 3.4 Reduction and desorption properties of the catalysts (H2-TPR and NH3-TPD) H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) is used to investigate the redox properties of supports and catalysts, as shown in Fig. 5 a,b. Two sets of broad reduction peaks, low-temperature peak (200–600°C) and high-temperature peak (700–900°C), are observed for all samples. Two reduction peaks for un-doped CeO2 located at about 490 and 780°C in Fig. 5a can be ascribed to the reduction of surface and bulk Ce4+ species, respectively [27]. The low-temperature reduction peak area of CeSn and CeTi is significantly larger than that of CeO2. The enhancement is mainly due to the synergistic effect between the dopants and Ce oxide in solid solution, which can create oxygen defects, and structural distortion [28]. Thus, Ti and Sn ions substitution improves reducibility of CeO2, which suggests that the mobility of surface oxygen was enhanced and beneficial to the SCR reaction. As mentioned in other studies, the interaction does exist between Ce and Ti, and the presence of Ti ions weakens the CeO bond in CeTiO x , which makes the CeO component be more easily reduced [29]. In Fig. 5b, the broad peak at 200–500°C belongs to the stepwise reduction of MnO x , i.e., MnO2 →Mn2O3 →Mn3O4 →MnO, overlapped by the reduction of surface Ce4+ [30]. Compared with Mn/CeO2, this peak of stepwise reduction of MnO x for Mn/CeTi or Mn/CeSn is broadened greatly due to good dispersion of Mn species and its interaction with corresponding support [31]. The amount and strength of surface acidity of the catalysts were probed by temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) analysis. As shown in Fig. 5c, NH3 desorption is observed over a wide temperature range, due to the variability of adsorbed NH3 species with different thermal stabilities. Desorption peak around 120°C is assigned to physical/weakly adsorbed NH3. The peak between 200 and 350°C can be assigned to the chemical/strong adsorbed NH3. The NH3 desorption peak of Mn/CeO2 was relatively weak, while it moves to higher temperature and the weakly and strong adsorbed NH3 both increase dramatically after the doping of Ti or Sn. Amounts of NH3 desorption (surface acidity) of the catalysts were obtained from the integral curves of NH3-TPD, and the area ratio among Mn/CeO2, Mn/CeSn, and Mn/CeTi is approximately 1:2.53:2.22. This suggests that NH3 adsorption on Mn/CeSn and Mn/CeTi is not only much more but also more stable than Mn/CeO2. The reaction mechanism of NH3–SCR in the presence of excess oxygen has been investigated extensively and the surface acidity is considered to be closely related to the catalytic activity [32]. Doping of Ti and Sn into Mn/CeO2 greatly increased the NH3 adsorption ability of the composites which could promote the SCR reaction. 3.5 Surface analysis of the catalysts (XPS) XPS analysis was carried out to study the surface chemical states of the fresh catalysts and catalysts spent in NH3–SCR SO2 containing reaction. XPS spectra of Mn 2p, Ce 3d, and O 1s are presented in Fig. 6 . Surface atomic concentration and ratio are summarized in Table 2 . The Ce 3d XPS spectra of the catalysts could be separated into ten peaks: v,v 0 (882.5eV), v′ (884.9eV), v″ (888.8eV), v′″ (898.3eV), u, u 0 (901.1eV), u′ (903.5eV), u″ (907.5eV), and u′″ (916.6eV). The marked v′ and u′ peaks are assigned to the Ce3+ species, and the denoted v, v 0, v″, v′″, u, u 0, u″, and u′″ peaks are associated with the Ce4+ species. For all catalysts, characteristic peaks attributed to Ce3+ and Ce4+ species are observed. The ratio Ce3+/(Ce3+ +Ce4+) can be estimated from the intensity of v′ and u′ peaks, according to the following equation where S v′ and S u′ are the intensities of v′ and u′ lines, and S v and S u are the intensities of v and u lines [33]: Ce 3 + ( % ) = S v ′ + S u ′ ∑ ( S v + S u ) × 100 The fraction of cerium in the 3+ oxidation state was used to evaluate the formation of oxygen vacancies and defect structure CeO2−x . As shown in Table 2, the doping of Ti and Sn to CeO2 resulted in higher proportion of Ce3+/(Ce3+ +Ce4+) on the modified catalysts surface, which can be attributed to the incorporation of Ti or Sn into the CeOCe species to form CeOTi or CeOSn structure. Oxygen vacancies driven by the transformation of Ce4+ to Ce3+ facilitate the activation and transportation of active oxygen species, which is beneficial to the reaction. After used in the SO2 containing reaction, the Ce3+ relative concentration of Mn/CeTi increase, but it decrease for Mn/CeO2 and remains unchanged for Mn/CeSn. According to the literature, it is a result of the following reaction: 2CeO2 +3SO2 +O2 →Ce2(SO4)3 when the catalyst was exposed to SO2 [34]. The Mn 2p XPS profile indicated that MnO x existed in the form of a mixed-valence manganese system on the surface of the catalysts. Two main peaks due to Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p3/2 were observed. By performing peak-fitting deconvolutions, the Mn 2p3/2 of mixed-valence manganese system can be divided into three characteristic peaks, which can be attributed to Mn2+ (640.4eV), Mn3+ (642.0eV), and Mn4+ (643.2eV), respectively [35]. The relative concentrations of Mn4+ was: Mn/CeTi>Mn/CeSn>Mn/CeO2. Previous studies have demonstrated that the higher oxidation state of manganese species (Mn4+) was preferable for redox properties over the manganese-based catalysts [36,37]. Thus, the higher Mn4+ concentration of Mn/CeSn and Mn/CeTi is in favour of a higher NO conversion. Through the characterization of spent catalysts, Mn concentration of Mn/CeTi–S shows almost no drop after SO2 containing reaction, but it decrease for the other two catalysts. This could probably be explained that the surfaces were partly covered with sulfates species. It indicates that Mn sites on Mn/CeTi are more likely to be released from being covered during the SO2 containing reaction, which is probably one of the reasons of its best SO2 resistance. We assume that sulfate species might preferentially form on CeTi support and lessening the sulfation of MnOx, which provides a protection of active sites from being poisoned. It was also been report by Wu and co-workers [13] that the addition of dopant to Mn/Ti catalyst might partially prevent surface Mn active sites of sample from being sulfated. So, doping of Ti may be an available way to improve the sulfur resistance of Mn/CeO2 catalyst. The O1s spectra of the catalysts are composed of two overlapping peaks. The first peak O′ in the range of 528.5–530.5eV is due to the lattice oxygen, and the second peak O″ in the range of 530.7–531.7eV corresponds to the weakly adsorbed surface oxygen [38]. When Sn or Ti was introduced, the peaks of O′ shifted towards higher binding energy due to the higher binding energy of the lattice oxygen in SnO2 or TiO2. The ratio of O″/O′+O″ is the highest for Mn/CeTi and lowest for Mn/CeO2. As reported by Ettireddy et al. [39], gas phase oxygen participated in the SCR reaction by filling the oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface, and the surface adsorbed oxygen enhanced the SCR activity. The process of oxygen storage and release between Ce3+ and Ce4+ has been proposed to occur by the following equations: (a) 2CeO2 →Ce2O3 +O* and (b) Ce2O3 +1/2O2 →2CeO2. The increase in the O″ content also promoted the conversion of NO into NO2 and improved the activities of the low-temperature SCR catalysts [40]. In addition, there are even more adsorbed oxygen species on the spent catalyst than fresh one, which was due to the oxygen of sulfate or hydroxyl on the surface. The above-mentioned XPS results indicated that Ti or Sn modified catalysts have more chemisorbed oxygen, Mn4+, and Ce3+ than Mn/CeO2, which contributes to the enhancement of SCR activity. Last but not the least, the peak position of Sn 3d and Ti 2p for Mn/CeSn and Mn/CeTi catalysts is found to shift toward lower bind energy respectively (Fig. S5), suggesting the existence of some Sn2+ and Ti3+ in the catalysts [41]. The existence of Sn2+ (or Ti3+) breaks the intrinsic charge balance. In order to maintain the electric neutrality, the valence of Ce changes between +3 and +4, as well as lattice oxygen migrates to the surface and takes off. This implies that dual redox cycles (Mn4+ +Ce3+ ↔Mn3+ +Ce4+, 2Ce4+ +Sn2+ ↔2Ce3+ +Sn4+) are available for Mn/CeSn. In the same way, Mn4+ +Ce3+ ↔Mn3+ +Ce4+, Ce4+ +Ti3+ ↔Ce3+ +Ti4+ exist in Mn/CeTi. Both of the cycles can promote each other and will result in a decrease in the energy required for the electron transfer among Mn, Ce, and Sn (or Ti) active sites. And the electronic transfer is closely related to the activation of NO and NH3 during the NH3–SCR [42]. The synergistic effect of the dual redox cycles is beneficial to the enhancement of the catalytic performance of NH3–SCR reaction, which is not available in Mn/CeO2 catalyst [43]. The promoting effects were also found by Chen et al. [44] for CuO/Ce x Sn1−x O2 catalysts in the selective oxidation of CO. It was attributed to the redox behaviors of Ce4+/Ce3+ and Sn4+/Sn2+ in Ce x Sn1−x O2 mixed oxides and the interfacial interaction between CuO and Ce x Sn1−x O2. 3.6 In situ DRIFTS Fig. 7 is the in situ DRIFTS of NH3 adsorption as the temperature rising from 50 to 400°C. The bands round 1606, 1176, and 1120cm−1 can be assigned to asymmetric and symmetric bending vibrations of the coordinated NH3 linked to Lewis acid sites [45]. The weak bands assigned to asymmetric and symmetric bending vibrations of NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites (1439 and 1645cm−1) [46] were also observed. It is found that intensity of the bands assigned to Brønsted acid sites decreased more noticeable than that of Lewis acid sites with increasing temperature. This indicates that ammonia bonded to Lewis acid sites were more stable than Brønsted acid sites. Moreover, intensity of the band assigned to Lewis acid sites over Mn/CeSn is more stable in higher temperature than that over Mn/CeO2. Intensity of band for Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites over Mn/CeTi are more stable than that of Mn/CeO2. The result is consistent with the above discussion of NH3-TPD. The adsorption and activation of NH3 are acknowledged to be a key step in NH3–SCR. And that, previous research showed that Brønsted acid site is beneficial for the adsorption of NH3, thus improving the low-temperature activity [47]. So, the results suggest that the introduction of Ti and Sn increased both the quantity and stability of Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites on the catalyst, which is beneficial for the adsorption of NH3, thus improving the low-temperature activity. Desorption of NH3 on Mn/CeO2 and Mn/CeSn is more serious than Mn/CeTi as the temperature goes up, which is a possible cause of their rapid decrease of activity. A promotion to N2 selectivity by a small amount of SO2 addition is also observed in Fig. S3. It could be attributed to the sulfate species formed on the surface which acts as a new acid site to improve the NH3 adsorption and inhibit oxidation of NH3 by O2, hence promotes the selectivity of the reaction.[48] Fig. 8 showed the DRIFT spectra of the catalysts in a flow of NO+O2 after the catalysts were pre-exposed to NH3 for 60min followed by N2 purging for 30min at 250°C. As shown in Fig. 7, the coordinated NH3 on Lewis acid sites (1169, 1219, and 1599cm−1) and –NH2 species (1542cm−1) formed on the catalyst with feeding NH3. Switching the gas to NO+O2, the intensities of all bands assigned to ammonia species decreased and vanished in 10min. Meanwhile, some new bands attributed to NO x species appeared. This fact indicates that the adsorbed ammonia species are reactive in the NH3–SCR of NO. Those assigned to bidentate nitrate (1572cm−1), momodentate nitrate (1547cm−1) and bridging nitrate (1212–1257cm−1) were also observed [49]. It should be noted that Mn/CeTi and Mn/CeSn show a band at 1235cm−1, which might be assigned to a bridge-bound nitrite or nitrate on Ce and Ti (Sn) sites, suggesting the existence of the CeOTi (CeOSn) structure [29]. Ten minutes later, a weak band at 1605cm−1 appeared. According to the literature [10], the band at 1605cm−1 was due to adsorbed NO2. The band at 1359cm−1 appeared on Mn/CeTi could be assigned to the intermediate species from the combination of surface adsorbed NH3 and NO x [50]. Therefore, more reactive intermediates (NO2, monodentate nitrate, MNO2 nitro compounds, and bridging nitrate) formed over Mn/CeTi catalyst, thus leading to the high catalytic performance. 4 Conclusion In this work, catalysts of MnO x supported on Ti or Sn doped CeO2 mixed-oxide (Ce0.8Ti0.2O2 and Ce0.8Sn0.2O2) was studied in the low temperature NH3–SCR of NO. It was found that Mn/CeTi and Mn/CeSn produced a better catalytic activity and broadening operating temperature window compared to Mn/CeO2 catalyst. Sulfur resistance of the catalysts for the SCR reaction was also improved by the doping. Greater than 90% NO conversion and 95% N2 selectivity could be provided by Mn/CeTi catalyst in the presence of 100ppm SO2 at 250°C for 10h. The characterization results revealed that the introduction of Ti or Sn into CeO2 resulted in catalysts with higher BET specific surface area, better redox property, and stronger surface acidity. Besides, there are more Ce3+ ions, Mn4+ ions, adsorbed oxygen species, and oxygen vacancies on the surface of Mn/CeTi and Mn/CeSn than Mn/CeO2, which is in favour of the reaction. CeTi support is supposed more likely to attract ammonia sulfate, which provides a protection of Mn active sites from being poisoned. The promoted SCR activity is also considered to be attributed to the synergetic effect of dual redox cycles exist in Mn/CeTi (Mn4+ +Ce3+ ↔Mn3+ +Ce4+, Ce4+ +Ti3+ ↔Ce3+ +Ti4+) and Mn/CeSn (Mn4+ +Ce3+ ↔Mn3+ +Ce4+, 2Ce4+ +Sn2+ ↔2Ce3+ +Sn4+). Thus, it can be inferred that the Mn/CeTi and Mn/CeSn catalysts may be a potential and environmentally benign catalyst for the low temperature NH3–SCR reaction. The relative research is expected to provide useful guidance for the development of promising catalyst toward NO x elimination for stationary source emissions. coredata.dc:description: Ceria-based solid solutions were synthesized and used as supports to prepare MnO x /Ce0.8Ti0.2O2 and MnO x /Ce0.8Sn0.2O2 catalysts (Mn/CeTi and Mn/CeSn) for low temperature selective catalytic reduction of NO by NH3. The effects of Ti or Sn doping on the catalytic performance of MnO x /CeO2 catalyst were investigated. Experimental results show that doping of Ti or Sn increases the NO removal efficiency of MnO x /CeO2. The NO conversion of Mn/CeTi catalyst is more than 90% at temperature window of 175–300°C under a gas hour space velocity of 60,000mLg−1 h−1. Modified catalysts are also found to exhibit greatly improved resistance to sulfur-poisoning. Characterization results indicate that doping of Ti or Sn brings about catalysts with higher BET surface area, enhanced oxygen storage capacity and increased surface acidity. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of spent catalysts following SCR reaction in the presence of SO2 verify that the loss of surface Mn species was inhibited by doping of Ti, which contributes to extend the sulfur durability. The SCR activity is considered as well to be promoted by the dual redox cycles in Mn/CeTi (Mn4+ +Ce3+ ↔Mn3+ +Ce4+, Ce4+ +Ti3+ ↔Ce3+ +Ti4+) and Mn/CeSn (Mn4+ +Ce3+ ↔Mn3+ +Ce4+, 2Ce4+ +Sn2+ ↔2Ce3+ +Sn4+) catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of metal ions doping (M=Ti4+, Sn4+) on the catalytic performance of MnO x /CeO2 catalyst for low temperature selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3
